newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee ends shade up on lack of dlr demand.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee ends shade up on lack of dlr demand.

text.p: The Indian rupee closed at 35.750/757 against the dollar on Wednesday, mildly up from the opening level of 35.755/765, dealers said.

"Ample dollar supplies continue to test the resolve of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI)," said a dealer at a foreign bank, referring to the central bank's perceived reluctance in recent days to buy dollars and arrest the rupee's rise.
The RBI stayed out of the market on Wednesday, dealers said.
Good dollar supplies and poor demand continued to characterise the spot market.
"Importers are buying only spot (requirements) but exporters are selling forward (dollars)," said a dealer.
One banker said only a month-end spurt in dollar demand could push back the rupee to the 35.80/90 per dollar level (at which it has been stuck for most of this year).
The rupee continued its rollercoaster ride against the forward dollar on the continued impact of RBI's April 15 monetary policy which prompted interest rate cuts.
The six-month annualised forward dollar premium closed at 4.35 percent on Wednesday, down from the previous 4.53 percent.
"Importers will wait for forward premium to bottom out before looking to hedge," a dealer said.
